Two summaries of opinions are shown below. Read carefully and answer according to your prior opinion. Both are scrollable.

Summary A

The comments reflect a wide range of perspectives on the tipping system, with a strong emphasis on the relationship between tipping and fair wages for service workers. A significant portion of the feedback criticizes the current tipping culture, particularly its overuse and the pressure it places on customers. Many argue that tipping should be reserved for situations where direct service is provided and should never be mandatory or implied. Some commenters express discomfort with the expectation to tip in fast food, takeout, or self-service settings, where they feel the practice is unnecessary or manipulative.

A recurring theme is the belief that service workers should be paid a fair, livable wage rather than relying on tips. Over half of the comments suggest that tipping should be eliminated or significantly reformed, with a service charge added to the bill instead. Others propose standardizing tipping amounts or making it more transparent and voluntary.

While some commenters support tipping as a way to reward good service, they emphasize that it should not be tied to poor wages or used as a way for employers to avoid fair compensation. A few suggest learning from international models, such as the fixed service charge used in countries like Japan.

Overall, the discussion highlights a desire for a system that is fairer to both workers and consumers, with a focus on eliminating financial pressure on customers and ensuring that service workers are not dependent on tips for survival.

Summary B

Overall summary of the comments:

  • Broad dissatisfaction with the current tipping culture, especially the sense of coercion from tablet prompts and requests in low- or no-service contexts (e.g., counter pickup). Many feel tipping has become over-expected and uncomfortable.
  • Strong support for shifting responsibility to employers: require a livable base wage (at least minimum wage for tipped workers) so income doesn’t depend on tips. Several favor moving toward a European-style model where service is included in prices.
  • Many want tipping to be optional and performance-based: tip more for good or exceptional service, less or none for poor service, and only after services are rendered—not beforehand.
  • Reform ideas include: replacing tipping with an automatic service charge (often modest) while keeping discretionary tipping optional; integrating service costs into menu prices; standardizing clearer, non-manipulative tipping guidelines; and limiting tip prompts to roles providing clear service.
  • Point-of-sale changes suggested: make “no tip” easy to find, avoid high default percentages, and don’t prompt for tipping in situations with minimal service.
  • A smaller set supports maintaining or even increasing tipping (e.g., fixed-amount tips instead of percentages, always tipping or overtipping), with one idea to offer acknowledgments or small incentives (thank-you notes, coupons) to recognize tips.
  • Additional notes: concerns about affordability for consumers, fairness to workers under the current system, and occasional proposals like making tips tax-free if tipping remains.
